isis.stitle: POWER STEERING GEAR: SHEPPARD M-SERIES - REASSEMBLE

svcproc.title: Service Procedure

step1.para: The M-series models use a seal ring on the end of the power piston. A new seal is installed by placing the back-up O-ring in the piston groove and installing the square cut seal ring over it ( Figure 75).

figure.caption: Figure 76. Install Square Cut Seal Ring

note.para: The seal material will stretch as it is fitted to the ring groove. If you let the piston set with the seal rings in place, it will become easier to install it in the piston bore. Use of a ring compressor is best to limit damage to the piston ring.

step1.para: Install a new sector shaft seal in the housing. Make sure the blue side of the seal is toward the outside of the housing ( Figure 76).

figure.caption: Figure 77. Install New Sector Shaft Seal

note.para: The housing will have a beveled chamfer on one end of the piston housing only. The piston will be installed through that end of the housing. Light taps with a soft hammer may be required on the end of piston to move it into the housing.

step1.para: At this time, you can reassemble the gear. Before installation of the piston into the piston bore of the housing, check for burrs on either the piston or piston bore. If burrs are present, they may be removed by polishing with a fine handstone or crocus cloth.
Coat both the piston and piston bore of the housing with a light coat of motor oil.
Carefully insert the piston into the piston bore of the housing, keeping the ball guide cavity exposed as shown ( Figure 77).

figure.caption: Figure 78. Insert Piston into Piston Bore

caution.para: Care must be taken when installing the piston in the housing. Close tolerances may cause the piston to jam in the housing bore. Any attempt to force the piston at that time could cause nicking or gouging of the housing bore.

step1.para: Install a new seal ring on the bearing cap and actuating shaft assembly ( Figure 78).

figure.caption: Figure 79. Install New Seal Ring

note.para: Cover the new seal ring with a light coat of grease to keep it in place during assembly.

step1.para: Insert the bearing cap and actuating shaft assembly into the piston as shown ( Figure 79).

figure.caption: Figure 80. Insert Bearing Cap and Actuating Shaft Assembly

note.para: Do not insert the bearing cap assembly completely. The bearing cap must be inserted to within 3 inches of the end of the piston.

step1.para: Install both halves of the ball guide into the ball guide cavity ( Figure 80).

figure.caption: Figure 81. Install Both Halves of Ball Guide

caution.para: Make sure the ball guides are pushed into the cavity all the way. Failure to do so during installation will result in the ball guides being pushed out of the piston during assembly. This will cause the balls to come out of track and binding will result.

step1.para: While supporting the bearing cap assembly with your hand, load the 24 steel balls in the ball guide. Slowly turn the bearing cap assembly inward while feeding the steel balls until all the steel balls are used ( Figure 81).

figure.caption: Figure 82. Load Steel Balls in Ball Guide

caution.para: Do not attempt to back the actuating shaft out of the piston during this process. This will cause the steel balls to bind on the actuating shaft and shaft damage may result.

important.para: Both halves of the ball guide must be held down when loading the balls to prevent the balls from coming out of their track.

step1.para: Install a new O-ring on the ball guide retainer and coat it with a small amount of grease. Insert the retainer over the ball return guide and into the ball guide cavity ( Figure 82).

figure.caption: Figure 83. Insert Retainer Over Ball Return Guide

step1.para: It will be necessary to tap the ball guide retainer into place with a soft hammer ( Figure 83).

figure.caption: Figure 84. Tap Ball Guide Retainer into Place

important.para: When properly installed, the retainer will be flush with the piston contour.

step1.para: If a bolt-on retainer is used, replace the seal ring on the retainer and install it in the piston cavity. Install the mounting bolts ( Figure 84, Figure 85, and Figure 86).

figure.caption: Figure 85. Install Mounting Bolts
Figure 86. Install Mounting Bolts
Figure 87. Install Mounting Bolts

caution.para: The internal tooth lockwashers must be installed on the mounting bolts. Failure to use these washers will result in a loss of torque and a possible loss of power assist.

step1.para: Tighten bolts to 12 ft-lbs. (16 Nm).

To install the piston, carefully work the piston ring past the sector shaft opening in the cylinder bore. While maintaining pressure on the end of the piston, press the piston seal into the ring groove. As the piston ring is compressed into the ring groove, the piston will slide further into the bore until the piston ring has passed the sector shaft opening ( Figure 87 and Figure 88).

figure.caption: Figure 88. Work Piston Ring Past Sector Shaft Opening
Figure 89. Press Piston Seal into Ring

step1.para: Install a new tetra seal on the bearing cap assembly and attach the bearing cap to the housing ( Figure 89).

figure.caption: Figure 90. Install New Tetra Seal

note.para: A small amount of grease on the tetra seal will help hold it in place.

step1.para: Install the bearing cap with the 4 longest screws. Tighten to the torque value in the TORQUE CHART( Figure 90).

figure.caption: Figure 91. Install Bearing Cap

note.para: If the bearing cap will not sit flush on the housing, be sure the bearing cap seal ring or tetra seal has not slipped out of place.

step1.para: Locate the timing mark on the piston rack and center the timing mark in the pinion bore of the housing by turning the actuating shaft ( Figure 91).

figure.caption: Figure 92. Locate Timing Mark on Piston Rack

step1.para: Install the sector shaft in the piston rack in the pinion bore.

important.para: The single timing mark on the sector shaft must line up between the two timing marks on the piston rack ( Figure 92).

figure.caption: Figure 93. Line Up Timing Marks

step1.para: It will be necessary to tap the end of the sector shaft with a soft hammer to make sure you have full rack and pinion engagement ( Figure 93).

figure.caption: Figure 94. Tap End of Sector Shaft

step1.para: Install a new sector shaft seal in the sector shaft cover ( Figure 94).

figure.caption: Figure 95. Install New Sector Shaft Seal

step1.para: Install the sector shaft cover and mounting bolts and tighten to values listed in the TORQUE CHART ( Figure 95).

figure.caption: Figure 96. Install Sector Shaft Cover

note.para: A light coat of oil on the sector shaft seal and cover seal ring will make installation easier.

step1.para: Place a new seal ring and tetra seal on the cylinder head ( Figure 96).

figure.caption: Figure 97. Place New Seal Ring and Tetra Seal on Cylinder Head

note.para: A light coat of grease on the seal ring and tetra seal will hold them in place during mounting.

step1.para: Attach the cylinder head to the housing using the four (4) remaining bolts. Tighten to specifications in the TORQUE CHART ( Figure 97).

figure.caption: Figure 98. Attach Cylinder Head to Housing

step1.para: Install the relief plungers in the cylinder head and bearing cap. Screw in the relief plungers till they are 1/8 inch (3.2 mm) below flush with the end caps ( Figure 98).

figure.caption: Figure 99. Install Relief Plungers

step1.para: Further adjustments are required. Refer to SET RELIEF PLUNGERS ( Figure 99).

figure.caption: Figure 100. Adjust Relief Plunger

step1.para: Install the dust cover on the end of the sector shaft and tighten lightly ( Figure 100).

figure.caption: Figure 101. Install Dust Cover

step1.para: Attach the mounting bracket to the gear housing using the attaching bolts and tighten to values listed in the TORQUE CHART ( Figure 101) (if equipped).

figure.caption: Figure 102. Attach Mounting Bracket to Gear Housing

step1.para: Install the rubber dust boot over the sector shaft ( Figure 102).

figure.caption: Figure 103. Install Rubber Dust Boot

step1.para: Install the steering gear on the vehicle.
Install the Pitman Arm on the steering gear. Refer to PITMAN ARM, INSTALL.

svcproc.para: After installation on the vehicle, bleeding of the system may be necessary. Refer to BLEEDING.
